translated: Stories of Departed Ones🔽The Chapter on Overflowing
The Story of the Thread-maker Departed One
“I used to approach a monk who had gone forth,
and ask for thread, and he would give it to me.
The result of that was the acquisition of abundant fruit,

analyzed: bahukā ca me uppajjare vattha koṭiyaḥ
translated: and many millions of garments arose for me.
My divine mansion is strewn with flowers, delightful,

original: Anekacittaṁ naranārisevitaṁ;🔽Sāhaṁ bhuñjāmi ca pārupāmi ca,
analyzed: aneka cittam nara nāri sevita  sā aham bhuñjāmi ca pārupāmi ca
translated: with many thoughts, frequented by men and women.🔽I eat and wear them,

analyzed: pahūta vittā na ca tāva khīyati
translated: and though I have abundant wealth, it is never exhausted.
By the continuation of the result of that deed,

analyzed: sukham ca sātam ca idhu upalabbhati
translated: happiness and pleasure are acquired here.

analyzed: sā aham gantvā punar eva mānusa
translated: Having gone there again, I will be human,
and make merit, good sir.”

analyzed: satta tuvam vassa satā idha āgatā
translated: “You have come here for seven hundred years,

original: Jiṇṇā ca vuḍḍhā ca tahiṁ bhavissasi;
analyzed: jiṇṇā ca vuḍḍhā ca tahim bhavissasi
translated: and you will be old and decrepit there.

analyzed: sabbe iva te kālakatā ca ñātakā
translated: All your relatives have died,

analyzed: kim tattha gantvānaḥ itas karissasi iti
translated: what will you do there, having gone from here?”

analyzed: satta iva vassāni idha āgatāya me
translated: “For seven years I have come here,
and I have attained divine happiness.
Having gone there again, I will be human,
What merit can I make, dear son?”

original: So taṁ gahetvāna pasayha bāhāyaṁ,🔽Paccānayitvāna theriṁ sudubbalaṁ;
analyzed: saḥ tam gahetvāna bāhāya  paccānayitvāna therim su dubbala
translated: He took her by the arm and pushed her away,🔽And brought the Elder Nun back, very weak;

analyzed: vajjesi aññam pi janam idha āgata
translated: “You have offended another person who has come here,
‘Make merit, happiness is to be obtained.’
I have seen that by not doing good,
Spirits are tormented, and so too are humans;
But having done deeds that are to be felt happily,

original: Devā manussā ca sukhe ṭhitā pajā”ti.
translated: The people who are established in happiness are gods and humans.”
The Story of the Ghost in the Thread is the eleventh.
